author: mpetrunic
content:
> Received goodbye request from 16Uiu2HAmAQE5mrh46ErJqEvW4MK6koKkWycV8oJBneC5pWbemgWC, reason=129 
Whats reason 129?

author: nishant0
content: Not part of the spec, but I know teku uses it to state that they are 'full', and so are not accepting new peers

author: benjaminion
content: Yes, can confirm that Teku uses the 129 reason for "too many peers".

author: mpetrunic
content:
<@!573787335796326400> 
Seems like teku doesn't return status response when there is "129" situation

author: mpetrunic
content: I see in logs I've sent status request, and I get from that peer goodbye request with 129 and no response for status

author: benjaminion
content: <@!545555441518772225> sorry, I need to defer to someone who actually understands the networking for the actual mechanics of that. Tagging <@!340345049063882753> for when the sun next rises in Australia...

author: ajsutton
content: <@!545555441518772225> I suspect we disconnect before we ever read the status request. We check if we've exceeded maximum peer count as soon as the libp2p handshake completes.  It may be worth being more forgiving about this so we start showing up in node crawling stats which never seem to find us.
